Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 10:26AM rn4babies wrote: Oh my, how I can relate to your experience! I too, am a "difficult" case.  I had calcs very close to the chest wall. The first attempt at biopsy was in December. This machine does not allow the prone position either. They could not pull me into the machine far enough to get to them so they said we'll wait until 6 months to see if they change. Well, they did get larger and now the bx HAD to be done. After repeated attempts, uncomfortable positioning etc, they finally got it! Guess what! He put the needle in my breast for the local and I passed out! I then pulled away from the machine when I got woozy. After I came to, they reattempted to locate the calcs again and could not. It was at that point he referred me to a top notch radiologist 2 hrs away because I was a "difficult" case. They had a machine that allowed the prone position with your breast hanging through a hole while you lay on your stomach. She described me as an "interesting" case. Anyhow, it went so much more smoothly. Still a little difficult to get to, but so much better. I did end up having a lumpectomy and there was again some difficulty getting the wire placed and the surgery took a bit longer but everything turned out well.  BTW, I am a nurse at the hospital that I had this done. Nothing bothers me and I have a high pain tolerance. Imagine how embarrassed I was when I passed out!
Posts.Title: Unsuccessful biopsy JodyJ JodyJ

Posts.Content: rn4babies wrote: I had my consultation with the RO today.  As soon as I got in the room the nurse asked me about the clinical trial the MO had asked me to participate in. When I told her I was still undecided, she did her quick assessment and told me get undressed and the doctor would be in. He came in, shook my hand and immediately did a breast exam (I have to admit it was the best one I've ever had). He never spoke a word to me during this and then said "she's done" and walked out of the room. The nurse told me to get dressed and go to the consultation room. The first words he said was "Her2" Because of his thick accent, I couldn't quite understand what he said. The nurse again asked me about the clinical trial (it is a Herceptin clinical trial). I told her I was willing to participate in it but didn't want to delay my rads for it. I then told him of my concern of heart issues because it is the left breast, close to the chest wall.  He just said "no concern". He told me the only possible side effect was some mild redness at the radiation site. I asked if fatigue was a possiblity and he emphatically said "NO!:" (That's not what my mother and aunt told me about their experience").  They again told me to think about the clinical trial and call them back. I was handed a folder and sent on my way.  I feel like the clinical trial is all they were concerned about. For insurance reasons, I cannot go anywhere else. Is this the usual treatment or am I being overly sensitive? I walked out of there almost in tears! First DX of DCIS on 7/7/11 of left breast. Lumpectomy with rads completed on 12/14/11. Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 05:44PM rn4babies wrote: Well, I arrived at the extremely crowded beach today for a long overdue vacation. Well.........as my luck would have it, as soon as I went in the water, a huge wave crashed in to me and my scarf came off in the water! I immediately covered my head with both of my hands (I'm only 5 weeks PFC and look like a baby ostrich) and another wave crashed into me, knocking me over. I put it on my head with a handful of shells, rocks and sand and hustled out of the ocean. I returned to our blanket covered in sand and rocks, scraped head to toe, crying.  Needless to say, I didn't return to the water today. I wish I was confident enough to go topless.....especially here at the beach!

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 10:24PM - edited Jun 13, 2011 10:26PM by rn4babies Tildymom.... I had two clusters of heterogeneous microcalcifications on my mammo in December, one a Birads 2 and the other a Birads 4. They recommended biopsy for the Birads 4 and 6 month followup for the Birads 2.  Although it was uncomfortable, it was not painful. The local did cause some pain initially. That Birads 4 was BENIGN and was diagnosed as PASH (fibrocystic changes). 6 months later, last month, My Birads 2 cluster is now a Birads 4 because they have increased in size. Because of the location (close to the chest wall), they were not able to get to the clusters and referred me to a specialist 2 hours away. My appt isn't until July 6th and I'm actually less stressed this time because I know what to expect and because my last one was benign and had the exact same characteristics.  BTW...I have a VERY strong family hx. Mother, aunt and sister all with BC. I think they are more concerned than I am. Just make sure you eat something before you go. That was a mistake I made this time.  Praying for B9 results for you!

Posts.Content: rn4babies wrote: I got the call today that my bx was positive for DCIS. Unbelieveably, I had an appointment already with my surgeon. He is an excellent surgeon, but a general surgeon that does alot of breast surgery. Anyway, I got my report after the appointment and am confused on a few things that he didn't mention to me. Here is a synopsis: Part1:  Left breast; with calcifications. Duct carcinoma in situ, solid and cribriform types, nuclear grade 3 with associated calcifications and focal suggestion of comedo necrosis. Part 2:  Left breast WITHOUT calcifications. Scant fragment of atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia suspicious for duct carcinoma in situ. COMMENT:  Part 2. Some tumor cells are fragmented and may be in a vascular space therefore the posibility of vascular space invasion may not be completely excluded.  The doctor did not mention the "comment" to me. Also, from what I am reading grade 3 and comedo necrosis can be related to a more aggressive type.   Does this mean there is a possiblility that there may be microinvasion? I asked if I could wait until the beginning of September to have the surgery as I have a 10 day vacation planned. He didn't think it would be a problem. My treatment recommendation at this time is lumpectomy with radiation. Am I making a mistake by waiting until September? Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2012 07:06PM rn4babies wrote: I was first dx'd with DCIS in July 2011, had surgery in September and finished rads on December 14th. My surgeon told me to wait 2 months before my next bilateral mammo so I had it in February 2012. It had been 15 months since my "good" breast had been checked. Lo and behold, I had IDC and ILC in the "good" breast. I'm not trying to scare anyone but please be sure to get your followup mammos on time. I finished chemo on July 16th and had #7/28 of my second round of rads in less than a  year.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 03:50AM rn4babies wrote: I had 2 areas of clustered pleomorphic calcs in December, Birads 4. One area was biopsied the other could not be due to the close proximity to the chest wall so they decided to watch those for 6 months. The first cluster was benign. PASH and fibrocystic  changes. I just had to go to a top radiologist 2 hrs away for the 2nd cluster (also Birads 4) which had increased since December (2 months from my mammo) and had my stereotactic BX on Wednesday. The results were supposed to be in today or Monday. I was at work when they called my house at 6:30. Now I have to wait until Monday! Hopefully they will be benign as well. BTW...family hx of mother, aunt and sister all with BC.Needless to say, this will be an anxious weekend of waiting for me!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 08:07AM rn4babies wrote: One advantage to being a nurse throught all this is being proactive about your treatment. I knew very little about breast cancer until this. Thank goodness I new enough to followup with everything or I probably wouldn't have even gotten any treatment. I feel bad for patients that aren't able to be proactive with their treatment.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2013 11:06AM rn4babies wrote: I have been a nurse for 17 years and I have never heard of such a thing. Good hand hygiene should be practiced at all times. If anything, I'd think it would be better because less elective surgeries are done during the holiday season and therefore staff would be less rushed. There is NO excuse for improper or lack of hand washing, however. As for instruments, my husband works in the central sterile department and their procedure for sterilization remains the same at all times. I'd have no reservation whatsoever having my surgery performed during the holiday season.
